headline: Apricot Cream Cheese Thumbprints
description: Apricot cream cheese thumbprint cookies always look so pretty on the cookie plates I give for Christmas.
name: Apricot Cream Cheese Thumbprints

recipeInstructions.text: In a large bowl, cream together the butter, sugar, and cream cheese until smooth. Beat in the eggs one at a time, then stir in the lemon juice and lemon zest. Combine the flour and baking powder; stir into the cream cheese mixture until just combined. Cover, and chill until firm, about 1 hour.

Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Roll tablespoonfuls of dough into balls, and place them 2 inches apart on ungreased cookie sheets. Using your finger, make an indention in the center of each ball, and fill with 1/2 teaspoon of apricot preserves.

Bake for 15 minutes in the preheated oven, or until edges are golden. Allow cookies to cool on the baking sheets for 2 minutes before removing to wire racks to cool completely. Sprinkle with confectioner's sugar.

review.reviewBody: Great flavor easy to make
How is it 2 additional hours? It's an hour to chill
great
Loved it. I was a touch more generous with lemon zest. And I refrigerated overnight. Made the next day. So good. Will be adding to my Christmas baking this year

I made these today and they turned out bland and boring. The thumbprint does not hold during baking and I have made a few thumbprint recipes. The cookie itself has zero taste.
Don't waste your time.

This is a great recipe. I used homemade cranberry orange sauce in place of jam on half my cookies & they were delightful?! I did not add any powdered sugar?. I think next time I’ll add a dash of salt to bring out the flavors. I couldn’t taste the lemon.? I did not add any powdered sugar, I didn’t it needed it. I use a small ice cream scoop to form the cookies and a wine~cork works perfectly for the intention and gets a nice deep well for the jam.?? I definitely will be making these again.?
Delious, soft and buttery cookies perfect to compliment my homemade preserves. I will be making them again for sure.
Yup, follow the recipe. Plowed snow half-way through so refrigerated dough overnight. Parchment paper makes life a lot easier.
I followed this recipe and I am amazed at how simple this was to make. I didn’t change anything.
These were absolutely wonderful! Everyone loved these! Bravo!

Delicious! I added more lemon juice than the recipe recommended and it added a nice zing to the flavour. The cookies came out a bit softer and mushier than I liked, would bake longer if I try this again.
I make this recipe and I double the cream cheese as some have suggested. I use guava jelly instead of apricot jam. It’s a big hit with my family and friends.

I followed the recipe exactly and chilled dough for two hours - used powdered sugar on my hands to make rolling a bit easier - delicious!!! And so pretty. Made half apricot and half strawberry. Will definitely make again!

I have made these for several years. I have tried multiple recipes and this is my favorite. I use different jams and they are always beautiful and moist. Look stunning on a plate. My dad asks for apricot every year.
I made these cookies and felt that there was too much flour. In looking at other recipes I found the flour was cut in half. They are gone but not what I remembered from childhood.
I used blackberry jam and cherries instead of apricot preserves Very good cookies :)
Made these for 1 of my Christmas cookies this year with my homemade Apricot Jam. Boy they came out great, my jam is tart so the combo was perfect!

I have been making theses for Christmas for a few years now. I double the lemon zest and juice to give more lemon flavor. I like a lot of lemon. They taste fresh and not too sweet. I have tried all different fruit preserves but apricot is still my favorite.

I made this recipe twice, once last Christmas and again yesterday, this is what Happened.
At Christmas, I made the recipe as stated minus the lemon zest and the cookies were to put it frank less than appetizing, not good.

Yesterday I thought I'd try it again so read the reviews and decided to add the extra 8 oz of cream cheese to total 16 oz which made the difference. I again left out the lemon zest.
My Family ate all the cookies as soon as they cooled on each batch, therefore the recipe with the extra cream cheese and minus zest earned 5 stars.

The dough is too sticky to work with and must be refrigerated. I did roll in the powdered sugar which also helped.

I will make again.
These were really yummy. I substituted orange for the lemon and it came out beautifully. Also added little salt.
soft and delicious. Might add more lemon next time but other than that, they are perfect!

I followed the recipe exactly, and it turned out great! They were gobbled up so fast, I barely was able to eat one myself. I admit, the cookie base tastes a bit like a biscuit. Despite this, these were delicious, and the apricot jam was the perfect sweet note. I will definitely make this again.

IF ANYONE WANTS A QUALITY, EASY BISCUIT RECIPE, 
omit the jam and sugar. It tastes exactly like Red Lobster's.
Maybe even add in some cheese and herbs for taste.

Great flavour. More cakey than shortbread.

I did add two full bricks of cream cheese, as others had recommended. Also used cake and pastry grade flour. Used apricot, blueberry, raspberry preserves for variety...blueberry and lemon is pretty awesome. 

The sticky batter texture was a but unruly, but I dusted my hands with a bit of flour. Drizzled white Belgian chocolate on the top (the wafers are sold at the bulk foods places).

All in all a nice surprise.

Great flavour. More cakey than shortbread.

I did add two full bricks of cream cheese, as others had recommended. Also used cake and pastry grade flour. Used apricot, blueberry, raspberry preserves for variety...blueberry and lemon is pretty awesome. 

The sticky batter texture was a but unruly, but I dusted my hands with a bit of flour. Drizzled white Belgian chocolate on the top (the wafers are sold at the bulk foods places).

All in all a nice surprise.

This is a nice cookie with just a hint of flavor depending on what jam you use. If you like sweet this is not the cookie for you. Cookie was very light, flaky and very mild flavored. The burst of flavor comes from the jam you use. I used assorted jams I had on hand. Sprinkled powdered sugar added for more sweetness.

These are fantastic. Not overly sweet and can be customized by using various preserves. I’ve tried them using both apricot and raspberry and both were fantastic. Can’t wait to try even more variations. Thanks for one of my new favorite cookie recipes!

made this for cookies give away. Everyone love them. I Made 3 different batches. One I made with Orange flavoring and orange and pineapple marmaladed. I also filled them with different jams. Some I sprinkle with power sugar, some I drizzle with melted white and chocolate. I will make them again.

I halved the recipe as I didn't need that many cookies. I ended up putting the full recipe amts. for cream cheese, lemon zest, and lemon juice trying to get some flavor in the cookie. I used a cherry preserve, which was fine...the cookie is very bland though. I was cooking 1-2 cookies (no jelly) at a time and tasting them before dough set up completely from cooling. I'm not sure what to add to fix it. I even added some salt to the dough, and that didn't help either. My fingers are crossed that after a few days, the cream cheese flavor will get stronger as another review said. It wad easy to put together, but tastes as if the ingredient flavors worked against each other instead of together. Won't make again.
Deliciously subtle flavored cookie! Perfect with just a hint of lemon. I made them with fig jam filling. I added some lemon zest and lemon juice to the fig jam. They are my new favorite cookie!
I will definitely make them again! This recipe is a keeper!
Will certainly make again!

This recipe is a good base recipe, I add a teaspoon of almond extract to really bump it up a notch. 

Be sure to make your thumb prints pretty deep as your preserves will melt a bit and it gives it more room to sit up as the cookie cools.

I use white chocolate drizzles to keep the cooking from being sticky on top and be able to package it easily.

Really great base recipe tho. You can tweak it to your preference flavor wise with vanilla etc, if you skip the citrus.

These turned out excellent! I had some Italian plums in the freezer so I thawed some and pureed them -and they were the consistency of jam. I did add some sugar to the plums but otherwise I followed the recipe as written. Yummy - just like shortbread cookies.
I doubled the cream cheese and added 1 Tbsp vanilla extract. I let the dough chill before rolling into confectioners sugar. Great recipe.

This is a good base recipe, but it required a bit of "bumping up" to make it less bland. I pretty much doubled the amount of lemon zest and lemon juice, and I added a splash of vanilla. Everyone loved them.

Worked great- used strawberry preserves. And my tip for perfect "thumbprint" indentation? A baby carrot. made nice fillable holes that turned out (after baking) looking like a thumbprint. Also put preserves in plastic sandwich bag and cut off corner to fill thumbprints

They turned out just like the picture but had no taste, very bland. I was so looking forward to a cream cheese cookie..I’ll try the Kolacky next time as they have less flour & same amount of cream cheese.
I made them. Was fast good and disappeared as I took them out of oven. Did as directed, except use different files .
Very bland and dry. I thought they would be sweeter. I really wouldn’t make these again.
I'm not sure if we cooked them for too long but we tried to cook them until they were "golden brown on the edges". These turned out hard and not that enjoyable at all.
cookies spread :(
The recipe needs to warn that if you use jelly instead of jam, it just melts and goes all over the cookie....

I made these during XMas time. They are delishious!! And so fluffy!
A few adjustments I made: double (low fat!) cream cheese (Philadelphia), double lemon zest, a bit more sugar, a yellow food coloring and two splashes of orange aroma.
After reading the reviews I used the measuring spoon for the indent and dipped it in water each time which worked a treat. Next time I will use a teaspoon for measuring out the portions as the cookies grew enormously and stuck together.

This cookie REALLY surprised me. I made this for a Christmas work party and everyone loved them! Normally I don’t care for apricot anything so I bought raspberry preserves just in case but I feel the apricot filled ones tasted better than the raspberry ones. They came out incredibly soft and the perfect amount of sweetness. The only difference I did was adding in an additional 1/2 block of cream cheese. Refrigerated the dough the night before and cooked it the next morning. Instead of using your thumb, I took a 1 tsp measuring spoon, dipped the rounded end in powdered sugar and pressed it into each cookie. I wanted a more rounded, professional look then sprinkled powdered sugar on top once cooled. These are now my favorite cookie!

I have made these for several years at Christmas and everyone loves them. Sometimes I add different zests or extracts. I have filled the thumbprint with every kind of preserve and have even filled cooled ones with chocolate ganache (yum-tastes like swiss fudge cookies). When I don't feel like getting too sticky from the preserves, I press a candied cherry in the center instead.

Perfect jam-filled cookies!!! I rolled some of the balls in crushed almond slices before indenting the and filling them. BTW, I used a homemade apricot jam and triple berry jam...sooooo perfect! The lemon zest and juice added to the crust made the flavor absolutely delectable. Thanks for the great recipe!
These cookies came out a little bland and tasteless to us. I would add a little sugar to the batter next time to add flavor.
These are delicious! Not overly sweet which is perfect for us! I needed to chill my dough longer in order to get it firm enough to work with. I used apricot and blackberry jams. Both are great!
Amazing ...moist and yummy
Disappointing. Followed recipe exactly, but they lacked flavor. I would not make these again.
made this tonite?. my family loves them. followed recipe up to vanilla extract, because I did not have it so I substituted maple syrup . .. yummy .

These cookies turned out very well! They are not a super sweet cookie which I like. Next time I will try doubling the cream cheese like 2 other reviewers did as I like rich cookies. I made these for Christmas using strawberry and peach jelly and they were so pretty. I do have to be careful and not make the cookies too big and do not overbake them, they will be slightly brown on the bottom and do spread out just a little while baking.
These turned out great! I used cherry preserves on some and blackberry on the rest. Very good!
These were fantastic! They were easy to make and probably turned out to be my favorite Christmas cookie this year!

These are my favorite holiday cookies now. Just know they take forever to make but are so worth it! I put apricot preserves in most of them and tried strawberry in a few. Very good--next year I will make half apricot and half strawberry or raspberry.
These cookies are the best! Crispy, yet light. I'm glad this recipe makes a big batch because they will be eaten very quickly. Like some other reviewers I did roll in powdered sugar before baking.

This is my first time making thumbprint cookies, and they turned out pretty well. I did scale the recipe back to about a third just because I wasn't sure how they would turn out. I ended up using 1/2c butter, 4oz cream cheese, 1/2c sugar, 1/2tsp baking powder, 1 egg, and 1 1/2c flour. I would use this recipe again.

These are pretty good, but maybe next time I will double the cream cheese and make them a little bigger and add more jam. I used apricot preserves in half and red raspberry jam in the other half. I actually preferred the red raspberry jam cookies better. They were slightly sweet.

These cookies are very good, I made them for my associates at work as gifts baskets and everyone loved them. I used several different preserves to get a variety.I love this recipe and will be making these again.

Made a batch of these a few days ago, refrigerated and baked them today. They turned out beautifully! I did half raspberry seedless jam and half apricot. As another reviewer suggested, I used a round measuring spoon to make the "thumbprints". I also put the jam in a ziplock bag and cut off the corner to neatly fill them. Worked like a charm! Oh--almost forgot! I used almond extract for flavoring instead of lemon/zest out of personal preference. These are great with a cup of coffee or tea and will add a pretty touch of color to my cookie trays!

I halved the recipe, added a few drops of vanilla extract and a bit more lemon than called for. Other than that, I followed the recipe exactly and they turned out great! I used apricot and raspberry preserves - so yummy with tea!

The dough was actually really easy to work with, I used raspberry and strawberry jam instead of apricot, it adds the extra umph that it needs. I followed instructions but I doubled the cream cheese as suggested but maybe next time I will try the original. Quick to make and you don't have to be a chef to e successful.

I used the cream cheese as one person suggested. The cookies are very good. The only thing is they take some time to make. between chilling the dough. rolling it in balls, putting the indent and then the jelly. They really take 15 minutes in the oven. If you are going to make these plan for them to take time. My daughter and I had an assembly line. I balled, she indented and filled with Jelly.

I make a variation of this by rolling them in pinwheel fashion. This recipe has been in my family for several generations. It is the favorite cookie at Christmas. It is a very subtle cookie that is a nice addition among all the really sweet stuff.. Even folks who claim they would not like these end up loving them!
these are delicious! not overly sweet, soft and tender. Fabulous. I used blueberry/lemon preserves and they turned out wonderful!
Delicious! Soft and melt-in-your-mouth cookies.
Followed recipe exactly. Rolled in powdered sugar before baking. Turned out excellent. Will definitely make again
I made this for a Christmas Cookie Club, and I loved them!! I did add 1 tsp of Vanilla, used the melon baller to help make even indentations. Beautiful jewel colored cookies!

I did everything on the recipe. I have a gas stove, so after 15 min in the oven at 350 degrees, it still was not fully cooked so I up the degree to 375 and added 6 more mins. I had my husband taste test it and he said it was pretty good.

These are the best Thumbprint cookies I have ever had. I followed the advice of one of the reviewers here, and doubled the cream cheese. I rolled them in crushed walnuts, put strawberry jelly on them, and then after they were baked, drizzled powdered sugar mixed with heavy cream and vanilla extract. They were fabulous!!!
I used solo apricot filling , after cooling added a little confection sugar.
This is an awesome recipe. Nothing else to say about it. Was a big hit with all of the in-laws.
Try with any jam! This a crowd pleaser for sure.

These were really good! I chilled the dough overnight. I dropped the balls of dough into confectioners sugar after rolling. To make the thumbprint part, I used the end of the handle of my plastic ice cream scoop, dipped in confectioners sugar. Used cherry preserves in place of apricot, and used lemon extract in place of the zest. Everyone loved them!
Yummy! Great cookie for the holidays.

This is the 1st review & 1st recipe I tried from this site. If you follow the recipe exactly as it is the cookies taste delicious-melt in your mouth. However, it is very difficult to make balls of the dough with indention and even rolling in sugar as some reviewers suggest doesn't help. The 1st few I baked as per the recipe and made the apricot paste filling at home so they look bland in the photo. The next lot I made, added color to paste and some more flour to the dough. The color was a welcome change and more flour made it easier to roll into balls but it affected the taste which was not melt-in-the-mouth but biscuity. Guess next time will just make them as they are without the thumprints:) 
P.S: I would like to know if they can be stored in an air-tight jar outside or need to be refrigerated so they don't get spoilt.

I have no idea why anyone would say these are bland, they have fantastic flavour. I have substituted the lemon for 1 tbsp vanilla and will change up the toppings. A spicy cherry jelly is fantastic, I also used guava paste which is sturdy enough it doesn't run off the cookie at all. I also like to try rolling the dough in different things before indenting and adding the jelly - so far crushed walnuts are the tastiest, sesame seeds look fantastic and powdered sugar adds delicacy and sweetness, I'm sure there are a lot of other things that would work too. My only issue is I actually find the dough to be too sweet, next time I will experiment with cutting down the amount of sugar and possibly adding more cream cheese if I want to work with a pepper or spicy jelly. 
Note - prep time seems incorrect for this recipe, rolling the dough and adding the jelly takes longer for me. Also I didn't make 7 dozen, I must have made my cookies larger but I ended up with 4 dozen.

I made these and drizzled them with a light frosting of milk/almond extract and confectioners sugar. Made them two days in a row by the dozens of dozens and people at work couldn't get enough of them. I was called evil for bringing something so delicious in to work that the girls starting their new years diets couldn't resist them!! Only thing I changed was to add a little vanilla extract and 1/2 teaspoon lemon extract instead of the zest. Then I rolled them in confectioners sugar to keep them from sticking. No need to add extra flour they turn out way better and lighter if you don't.

This recipe is a definite keeper! I am an avid baker and often rely on the ratings of others before I will bring it to the table for my family. Since this was rated so highly, I gave it a try and made a few changes. I followed the advice of others and rolled these in powdered sugar to make for easier handling. I also used cherry preserves and when cooled, I made a powdered sugar glaze with milk and added a teaspoon of almond extract to it. The cherry and almond flavoring combo was divine. I also made the other half of the batch using apricot preserves and also drizzled the almond glaze over these, too. What a delicious treat! They are a cross between a sugar cookie with glaze and a classic thumbprint with preserves. You will not be disappointed with these tender cookies. Tip: Use parchment paper when cooking so the preserves don't leak out on the sheet pan. Of course, this will only happen if you push down too much on the cookie for the jam insert. A teaspoon worked perfectly when I dipped it in powdered sugar to form the jam divot. Plus, using parchment deters the cookie from browning too much on the bottom.
Great cookies, also added two teaspoons of vanilla extract like other reviewers mentioned . Turned out really good.

I made these exactly as recipe said, and I didn't care for them. The dough was kind of gummy, and bland. I used orange marmalade and strawberry preserves, as there is allot of dough.they were sweet, and that's due to the jelly. Something is missing.Will try another recipe next time.

These were delicious cookies! The cream cheese gave them a wonderful texture and tang. I used homemade blueberry jam instead of apricot, which stained the surrounding top of the cookie a purple color, but that's the fault of the jam. A very versatile recipe that has quickly become a favourite at my house.
These were ok. The cookies had more of a bisquit consistency than that of a cookie.

Really liked these cookies. Just made them for the husband for Valentines Day. I add a 1/4 tsp salt, and I also added 1/2 tsp almond extract along with the lemon juice. I only made a half batch, didn't really want 7 dozen cookies. I got 4 dozen. I also used apricot filling that I buy near the bakery section of my food store . It's niot as runny as preserves and is totally apricots, no sugar added. I rolled the balls in granulated sugar, that's what I do when I make kolachy..they were great, will make again
Delicious!! They were a huge hit! Will make again. I added more lemon zest to mine.

I thought these were a little bland. Thank goodness I read prior reviews and added some vanilla extract. They were just a cookie to me. I did roll the cookies in conf. sugar before baking and that I am sure helped with the flavour a bit.

I needed a second cookie for a holiday luncheon and had some cream cheese to use up so this recipe fit the bill. I halved the recipe. I skipped the lemon juice and zest and instead added some almond and vanilla extracts. I unfortunately had only some cheap raspberry jelly to use which ran out of the cookie and all over the cookie sheets but that was the fault of the jelly. I will be sure to make these again with the lemon flavoring and the apricot jelly. Thanks!
Loved these! Nice, light texture and the apricot adds just the right amount of sweetness. I stuck close to the recipe: I left out the lemon zest and added 2 tsp of almond extract. Yum!

I actually baked them today, it works better to keep then dough chilled in between oven batches. I prefer using either strawberry, cherry etc jams (reds) just because apricot was so overused in my family for cookies. The cream cheese keeps them moister than other recipes I've tried.
i love these things. they're dangerous.
These are easy and wonderful! thanks for the recipe!

I made these for work and everyone loved them. They are nice because the are not super sweet but very buttery. I used raspberry and strawberry preserves but will use apricot next. I followed the recipe except I didn't have lemon juice but they were still fantastic.
Delicious - They were on the plate - now they are gone. Fast easy preparation - I didn't make any adjustments.
This was awesome. I love Kolacky but don't love the work involved rolling out the dough, this was a great substitute, so easy and so good!

these are the best thumbprints I've ever had. I did increase the lemon juice to 3 tablespoons and the lemon zest to about 2-1/2 teaspoons. I did not change anything else. Perfect! 
For variety, I rolled some in decorative white crystalized sugar and filled with orange marmalade, Solo Apricot filling, or Solo Raspberry filling. Just wonderful.
So easy and delicious. I use different preserves. Blueberry is the best.
Butter + cream cheese + apricot ALWAYS = delicious! The dough was a little too sticky and the first batch didn't hold their shape, but after adding a little more flour they worked out perfect.
Delicious and delicate.

These are absolutely wonderful! I used apricot peach jam and I also added 1/2 tsp salt to 1 batch. For those of you who thought it was bland, try adding the salt. Brings out flavor and most cookies do have salt for a reason. I want to use double raspberry jam next time. This one is a keep for sure!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
